name: silicon tetrahydride production, silicon hydrochlorination | silicon tetrachloride | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9099/documentation

This dataset represents the production of silicon tetrahydride (SiH4) and silicon tetrachloride (SiCl4) by hydrochloration of silicon to trichlorosilane, followed by the disproportionation of trichlorosilane. Silicon tetrachloride is a clear, colorless liquid that fumes strongly in air and hydrolyzes rapidly in water, producing SiO2 gel. It is used for the production of high-purity silicon, highly dispersed silica, as well as corrosion-resistant coatings for metal surfaces. Silicon tetrahydride is used to deposit silicon on surfaces such as glass or silica-coated surfaces. This dataset is based on literature data as well as data from similar processes.;References:;Simmler, W. 2000. Silicon Compounds, Inorganic. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.

From the reception of metallurgical grade silicon and hydrochloric acid at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the trichlorosilane hydrogenation process, including the consumption of raw materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the world.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Hydrochloration of silicon and disproportionation of trichlorosilane are the most important processes to produce silicon tetrahydride.;Industrially, silicon tetrahydride is produced from metallurgical grade silicon (MG-silicon) in a two-step process. In the first step, powdered silicon is reacted with hydrochloric acid at about 300 °C to produce trichlorosilane, HSiCl3, along with hydrogen gas, according to the chemical equation:;Si + 3HCl → HSiCl3 + H2;The hydrogen is re-used in other silicon purification processes and therefore not considered as co-product. In the second step, catalytic disproportionation of trichlorosilane results in SiH4 and SiCl4. For a mixture of trichloro- and dichlorosilane, copper, a mixture of silica and alumina at 300 °C, and quaternary ammonium groups bonded to carbon in an ion-exchange resin have been reported as catalysts for the main reaction leading to silicon tetrahydride. ;4 HSiCl3 → 2 H2SiCl2 + 2 SiCl4;2 H2SiCl2 → SiCl4+ SiH4;Purification ;In-process purification is achieved by contacting part of the silicon tetrahydride produced with the starting mixture of chlorosilanes, which contains the impurities as chlorides, chiefly those of arsenic, phosphorus, and boron. This procedure converts the contaminants into their more volatile hydrides, which are removed with the off-gas.;Removal of boron compounds from silanes that are to be used for the production of high-purity silicon is very important. When SiH4 is produced from alkali metal hydrides, it is recommended that water should be added to hydrolyze boron hydrides under the alkaline reaction conditions. Water vapor is added during distillation for the same reason. Boron compounds can be removed from SiH4 by adsorption from the gas phase onto activated carbon or silica carriers loaded with compounds that form complexes with boron compounds (AlCl3, FeCl3, C2H5CN, NH2CN, PCl3).;If alkali metal hydrides MH are reacted in organic solvents, it is often unnecessary to include a special stage for removing boron compounds from the silicon compounds, as the former react to form boranate complexes under the following conditions: ;References:;Simmer, Walter: Silicon Compounds, Inorganic. Published online: 2002. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/emrw/9783527306732/home
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Energy consumption, emissions and infrastructure are estimated based on data from a similar process.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Emissions to water from the silicon hydrochloration process are estimated from the production of electronic grade silicon

Estimation. The energy consumption for the silicon hydrochloration process is estimated from the production of electronic grade silicon. In this dataset an amount of 150 kWh electricity and 160 MJ heat per kg EG-silicon are considered. This values are also used here.The electricity is calculated with the mix that is considered in the literature data.
